headline: 2020 Democrats admit past pot use, embrace legalization
subHeadline: Democrats back legalizing recreational marijuana; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, POLITICAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Hello everyone. I'm Juan Williams, along with Jedediah Bila, Jesse Watters, Dana Perino, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City. This is “The Five.” The impeachment battle boiling over on Capitol Hill. Republicans now demanding to know when and who the whistleblower is. And they want that person to testify publicly.  It comes as President Trump is praising House Republicans as, quote, "tough and smart" after they stormed the closed-door impeachment hearing. Today, Senator Lindsey Graham introduced a resolution condemning the inquiry. He and other Republicans not happy with how the process is playing out.

utterances.speaker: SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM, R-S.C.
utterances.sentences: I think if we were doing this you'd be beaten by (muted) of us. I think if a Republican were doing to a Democrat what we're doing, you would be all over me.

utterances.speaker: REP. STEVE SCALISE, R-LA
utterances.sentences: Maybe in the Soviet Union this kind of thing is commonplace.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We've got to stop like thinking that we can use the marquis of Queensberry rules of engagement when we're fighting against the angry pack of rabid hyenas.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Democrats say they will make the impeachment inquiry more transparent with plans for public hearings as soon as mid-November, but they are not backing down. Take a look at Democrats and the media attacking the GOP's tactics.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It looked like a mob scene.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And they are not flash mobbing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Acted like a mob.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Described the scene like a mob.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Like a mob.

utterances.speaker: MAX BOOT, CNN GLOBAL AFFAIRS ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Lawless mob action.

utterances.speaker: LAURA COATES, CNN LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Mob mentality.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: So, what happened yesterday was a high school prank by a bunch of 50-year-old white men.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You just saw a bunch of white men.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Those are white guys. Those are middle-aged boring nerdy looking white guys.

utterances.speaker: JEFFREY TOOBIN, CNN CHIEF LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: They looked like just jerks.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Pathetic weenies.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's almost out of the animal house movie.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Just as mad. How do you go home and look at your wives and look at your children?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Well, I think most -- I think --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Just a pathetic, pathetic people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right, Jesse, everybody has got their take on this one way or another. But, I mean, even the Wall Street Journal called that a stunt today. But I would you when you see the Republicans in parts, storming that secure hearing room, aren't they violating House rules? I mean, I think they should be more upset with the founding fathers who wrote the Constitution and said this is the way impeachment is to be conducted rather than just the Democrats.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.sentences: They want to know the truth. They want to know what's going on behind closed doors. Both parties have stunts. The Democrats are the king of stunts. I mean, they ate the fried chicken in the room. They all do sit-ins over guns. The mob action, the Democrats love mob action. That's what they've been doing the less three years. But unfortunately, Juan, this is what happens when you lose elections. The Democrats outvoted the Republicans in the midterms. Pelosi has the gavel. They can do whatever the hell they want. And the Republicans are force to pull the stuff.  It's really people who stayed home on election day last time. I mean, if you want to point fingers, they needed more Trump voters and they didn't get them. And now, Trump is getting eaten alive by people on the inside.  First it was Comey and McCabe. The transition was a horror show. And then there was all these people working against him, an embassy at the National Security Council and he can't get anything done because every time he tries to do one thing or the other, people cut him down in the dark. And it's really disgraceful. Ukraine is the most corrupt basically, on the entire planet. This place is a mess. We send them billions of dollars. Everyone is getting rich over there, including the Biden family. They colluded with the Democrats last election. It's a Russian speaking country. It's totally a mess. And all the president is trying to do is find out what the hell is going on over there, find out what happened last time, how is everything starting to begin with. He's playing politics. He's trying to fight back. And he's getting killed for it.   Now, they are holding secret impeachment hearings. It's disgusting. And all the Republicans want to do is find out what's happening behind closed doors and they can't even share their side of the story, because all the whistleblowers and their lawyers have colluded with Schiff in order to tee this ting up.  Now does anyone even care in the administration? They don't even have a team that's fighting this thing. I mean, I've said more things on the show to push back against what's going on than I've seen out of the White House. Where is the Senate? Where is Lindsey Graham? Why isn't he holding hearings? Why isn't he interviewing the people that are testifying behind closed doors?  It's time for them to get tougher than they already are. You know, you can say I condemn this. You can send a bunch of guys in to try to find out what's going on, but they need lawyers, they need killers, they need people with experience, parliamentarians who know who to fight this thing. Because right now, it's day after day, week after week, and they are losing the message war.

utterances.speaker: JEDEDIAH BILA, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Tell us how you really feel.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Do you think they need Jesse Watters? I think they need Jesse Watters. Greg, the president though, takes Jesse's position. He says you know what, he encouraged them to pull that stunt. In fact, he says now that Republicans who oppose him are, here I'm quoting, "human scum."

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Worse than the most dangerous Democrats. How do you react to that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. He called them human scum. It could have been worse; he could have called them Democrats. Joke. I love the Dems. By the way, I feel bad for the Democrats and the media. They were preferring a Mitt Romney who got Candy Crowley. You don't have it in the White House now. This guy likes to punch back and he's going to do it. Donny Deutsch calling someone a weenie. This guy is an eight-pack of ball park franks. I mean, he still wears Speedo's under his suit. OK. That's what a weenie is.   But here's the deal. Calling those Republicans out as a bunch of white guys, what you're doing is you are injecting color into something where it has no relevance. So, what's that -- what's that called when you inject race into something where there is no racist variable? It's called race- baiting. So, CNN and MSNBC are engaging in something incredibly pretty dangerous. They always have it. It's getting pretty bad. They are seeking to divide a country based on pigment. That's what they are doing. And when I see that, it makes me realize how awful the media is. And if you subtracted the media from the story, we probably get closer to the truth. And to be honest, the truth is the media and the Democrats would prefer only one kind of resistance, their own. Which is why they are calling these guys a mob. That's why they create hate hoaxes. They demean supporters. They fabricate racial animus.   They do that because they're trying to scare the way they scare like anybody who believes their pack, whether it's Candace Owens or Peter Thiel. If they're not, you know, if you are black and you are not a liberal, if you are a gay and not a conservative, you're dead.  So, I just think, I think it's good to fight back. I don't think it was a mob. They are doing the job that the journalist -- like journalists prefer to get it spoon-fed to them from Adam Schiff.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The Republicans are actually doing what journalists are doing. They are knocking on the door and saying, give us the facts.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, in fact though, here we have a situation, Dana, where it looks like they're complaining about process. Complaining about the whistleblower. Always the whistleblower someone with some political affiliation opposed to the president.  They are complaining about things because the facts as we understand them from these hearings, are really hurting the president.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: What they are saying is that they don't -- you don't have enough transparency to be able to make that determination. That's what the Republicans are saying. And we know the saying if you, if the facts are on your side, pound the facts.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And if not, pound the table.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And so, this is called a stunt by the media and it was a stunt. But remember when AOC first got to Congress and when the first act that she did was go and sit-in on Nancy Pelosi's office to protest climate change. That was a protest and that was considered something like that was you're exercising your right. And it was bringing good attention to something. But when Republicans do it, then it's called a stunt. Either way, it works in order to get yourself in the media. And basically, the Republicans were able to win a news cycle yesterday. They hadn't been able to do it, to Jesse's point up unto now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, do you think though, Jedediah, that when we talked about the whistleblower, is there, from the Republican perspective, a fundamental misunderstanding of the law? Because the reason there is a whistleblower law is to protect the whistleblower against intimidation or pressure coming from powerful people like the most powerful man in the country, Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I think that's typically true. The problem with the whistleblower is that there have been so many inconsistencies in terms of what that person has said. There are these allegations now of serious political bias, of not only being a registered Democrat but having worked with high-profile Democrats in the past.  There is this concept of the secondhand information, where did this whistleblower get that information? How credible are those sources? And then also just the fact that the whistleblower didn't check that box that said yes in fact he had spoken to the likes of Adam Schiff ahead of time. So, I think all of the questions around the whistleblower are the problem. So, Republicans, I'm not a big fan of them storming a hearing. That's all nonsense. But I do think that they are concerned about Adam Schiff as being an honest person is real. I mean, he has lied repeatedly several times throughout this. And also, just concerns about the whistleblower. In this particular case, seem -- seems to be more concern. I would be looking at this and saying, we need to hear from where this information came from.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: From the whistleblower.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Well, yes, because there's too many red flags. It's uncomfortable.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I'm thinking a whistleblower's account-

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: But I understand what you're saying about the law.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right, the law is obvious.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I'm saying that his account also then has been confirmed on so many levels by what we've learned. But --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: But it also has a ton of holes in it is the problem.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This whistleblower is what's important than the actual transcript of the phone call.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Which we already heard.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We know what happened. Nothing bad happened.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And it was perfect.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is all a circus.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It was a perfect --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: it was perfect.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, you believe that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Like my jacket.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I got a bridge for you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Democrats are going after Facebook with pointed attacks against CEO Mark Zuckerberg. Gregory fills you in on that next on “The Five.”

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: People mock Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg for his but-like demeanor and appearance. But would you react to this.

utterances.speaker: REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ, D-N.Y.
utterances.sentences: In your ongoing dinner parties with far-right figures some of who have advanced the conspiracy theory that white supremacy is a hoax. Did you discuss so-called social media bias against conservatives and do you believe there is a bias?

utterances.speaker: MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, FACEBOOK
utterances.sentences: Congresswoman, sorry, I don't remember everything that was in the -- in the question.

utterances.speaker: CORTEZ
utterances.sentences: That's all right. I'll move on. Can you explain why you've named the Daily Caller a publication well-documented with ties to white supremacist as an official fact-checker for Facebook?

utterances.speaker: ZUCKERBERG
utterances.sentences: Congresswoman, sure. We actually don't appoint the independent fact-checkers. They go through an independent organization called the independent fact-checking network. That has a rigorous standard for who they allow to serve as a fact-checker.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What a contrast between showboating for clicks and basic politeness. At least Facebook's A.I. has some I. Remember, while Zuckerberg created a company that employs thousands, AOC prevented Amazon from employing thousands in the city that she represents. Zuckerberg's big question is how do I connect to billion people versus how did I do want TV. It gets worse.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It's almost like you think this is a joke. When you have ruined the lives of many people, discriminated against them. Do you know what percentage of African-Americans are on Facebook in comparison to the majority, folks? Do know what the percentages are?

utterances.speaker: ZUCKERBERG
utterances.sentences: People who are using the Facebook?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Do you know what the percentages are for African-Americans?

utterances.speaker: ZUCKERBERG
utterances.sentences: I don't because we don't collect the races of --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Well, it came out in a report and in the Pew Research Center that was sent to you. So maybe you just don't read a lot of things that have to do with civil rights or African-Americans.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So, where are all the facts-checkers in this? The journalistic showboats holding these politicians accountable when they create phony smears? I guess Brian Stelter is busy spell-checking Trump's tweets. My favorite, take it away, Al.

utterances.speaker: REP. AL GREEN, D-TX
utterances.sentences: Are there any members of the LGBTQ plus community associated with this association, Mr. Zuckerberg?

utterances.speaker: ZUCKERBERG
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I don't know the answer.

utterances.speaker: GREEN
utterances.sentences: Who can -- who acknowledge that many who acknowledge that they are part of the community?

utterances.speaker: ZUCKERBERG
utterances.sentences: Sorry?

utterances.speaker: GREEN
utterances.sentences: You do not -- you do not know?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wow. Zuckerberg doesn't know how many gay people work on an idea. That's a huge problem. So, after the show, we are going to get the whole Five staff together and then we're going to ask them if they like men, women, or both. Because, yes, I think that's totally legal. Fact is, nobody in that room will ever do more to help more people than the geeky guy they slimed with idiotic questions. it's pure scapegoating. Still unable to accept blame for 2016. They find a sacrificial pinata and beat the stuffing out of it in their home turf where they hold the gavels, they made suck into a straw man and set fire to him. I have no idea what Zuckerberg's politics are, but after that hearing, I know what they should be. He should despise big government and its enablers. He should cling to free markets and free minds and never take these clowns seriously again.  Maybe he should stop being so polite. They want to destroy you, Mark. Next time D.C. comes calling, let it go to voice mail. So, Dana, what do you -- how do you grade his performance with the -- I mean, handling it that calmly with face -- like arrogance is pretending you know something that you know nothing about. And that was a lot of arrogance.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And it went on for hours and hours. And he never lost his cool. And he, I think that he is so exceedingly cautious with his words, because one, he doesn't want to offend people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He also recognizes that he -- he serves two billion customers. Two billion -- there are two billion people on Facebook. Those are people that are family and friends, people running businesses, people doing news, all sort of different things. And anything that he says can move a market --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- in a second, right? He talks about losing a billion -- $100 billion in one day when they moved to the news staff but then it was the right thing to do. When you ask him if he'll be polite in the future, so Washington, there are several factors coming together. One of them is the antitrust factor with some people on Republicans and Democrats saying it's a monopoly and should be broken up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You have to ask yourself. Do think Washington can handle things better than a private company?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: God, not after seeing that. Juan, how can she ask him or say with a plain, you know, face, you've destroyed the lives of African-Americans? How can you say that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I think it's Bernice King whose Dr. King's daughter earlier this week after Zuckerberg spoke at Georgetown and he cited Dr. King and said, you know, well, you'd want minority opinions represented. She said, hey, you know what, it was political disinformation that led to his assassination.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think destroy --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, I think that a lot of people would have problems. Here's the thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He destroyed the lives, that's what she says.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well here's what I think, Greg. I find this very curious that conservatives for most of Facebook's like have said, you guys are biased against conservative content. But now, all of a sudden, they are defending Zuckerberg. Why is that? Because he will let Trump do whatever he wants. He will not check political lies on political ads. And he says it's free speech.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He said he would.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The simple solution. I've said this before. Why is he taking political lies? If he doesn't want to stop the lies and the hatred on his Facebook, he should say look, but I don't need political ads.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's a great way to hurt minorities.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, it's not.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, it's not.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, it is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think it's a way to help. Because the hate speech --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, it is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- he checks -- he checks backs on other ads but he won't check him on political ads and it's a gif to Trump.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: So, you think Zuckerberg though is supposed to sit there now and look through every political ad?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no. What he just talked about --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: And what's deemed as biased isn't going to be all subjective. What's deemed as incorrect. I mean, AOC is talking about this topic. You look at her whole Twitter feed, it's full of a bunch of nonsense, a bunch of lies.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You can say nonsense. Why a lie is different than nonsense?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: A bunch of stuff that I would say is totally misleading.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Is it.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: And he is being defended, Juan, because this is harassment. This guy went in there to answer some questions and he got abused and he got harassed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They mean to say, Jedediah --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: He's -- they are asking him if he's -- if he knows the race and sexual orientation --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's all --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: -- of all the people. Like he -- shouldn't he mean --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: People ask are you --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Is that he should be asking? I'm sorry. What is your sexual orientation?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: This is so common in America.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, it shows how little they know.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: That's crazy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You don't talk to people you are working with, Jesse. You don't go like you don't to staff, so I need to know your sexual orientation. That is moronic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You would lose your job.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. I do want to talk to you about it. We'll talk in the break.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, I haven't made up my mind yet.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: He's working on it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm working on it. I'm LGBTQRXY and Z.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, to Juan's point --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'll guess that sometimes Y.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Sometimes Y.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, what was the political ad --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Why not?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- that Trump pushed out in Facebook that was filled with lies?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Gosh, I could -- I could stack them up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What's --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Lately, it's all about impeachment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The Democrats are conducting an illegal process it's --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- Constitution. It's in the Constitution.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's OK. OK. So, saying that impeachment is unconstitutional, that is a lie --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- and that should not get --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's a lie.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's an opinion.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's an opinion, Juan. The way they're doing impeachment --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- he thinks is unconstitutional.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No. He's doing that to stir up his base with lies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan, that's not a lie. It's an opinion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: There it is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: My point is --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Greg said to me, who cares if he lies?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly. It's an opinion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And it's not my problem.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And when AQOC puts out an ad that says the earth is going to die in 12 years --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Is that --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, that's election -- if she can't substantiate it, get it out. But I don't know that she can substantiate.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, it's more of a lie to say we're going to die in 12 years.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I see. You guys are jumping now because you know what, that's a losing --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. Remember this?

utterances.speaker: BILL CLINTON, FORMER PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: I experimented with marijuana a time or two and I didn't like it. And didn't inhale --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Smoking marijuana used to be a taboo subject for candidates running president. You might remember when Bill Clinton shocked the nation by admitting this.

utterances.speaker: CLINTON
utterances.sentences: I experimented with marijuana a time or two and I didn't like it. And didn't inhale, and never tried it again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, times are changing and our country has since evolved. Many 2020 candidates are now admitting to smoking pot as they call as they call for a nationwide decriminalization. Mayor Pete Buttigieg is just the latest example.

utterances.speaker: MAYOR PETE BUTTIGIEG, D-IND., PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: I had a handful of times a long time ago. And I've also encountered a lot of people whose lives have really been shaken by the old war on drugs approach.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And Mayor Pete is not alone.

utterances.speaker: CHARLAMAGNE THA GOD, CO-HOST, THE BREAKFAST CLUB
utterances.sentences: Have you ever smoked?

utterances.speaker: SEN. KAMALA HARRIS, D-CALIF., PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: I have.

utterances.speaker: GOD
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: And I -- and I did inhale.

utterances.speaker: GOD
utterances.sentences: You did inhale.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: It was a long time ago. But yes.

utterances.speaker: GOD
utterances.sentences: Have you ever smoked?

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS, I-VT, D-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: A few times.

utterances.speaker: GOD
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: I didn't do a whole lot for me. My recollection is I nearly call for my brains out, so it's not my -- my cup of tea.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I mean, Bernie might have been the most honest one. Bernie Sanders also releasing a new marijuana plan. He wants to have a legalization of marijuana for in the first 100 days of his presidency if he's elected. And he says he will do for this executive action and create a White House clemency in board that would help all those people that have low level of marijuana offenses. So, I'm not a big expert in this field. I'm glad I'm leaving this so I could just ask you. What do you think, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, you left out two other candidates. Joe Biden admitted to mainlining (Inaudible). And Liz Warren also says she smokes a peace pipe regularly. Anyway, I love how -- finally politicians have moved away from saying I experimented with drugs, as if you were like an Isaac Newton in your dorm room, with that cradling a bang for four years. yes, I experimented. Or it's like, or like I think I'm pretty sure he said I tried it a handful of times. Nobody tries drugs. You do drugs, OK? You can try mountain climbing or you can try -- but when you're doing the drugs, it goes inside your body. You are no longer trying them. They are inside you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I experimented with mountain climbing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I experimented. It drives me crazy. And also, the handful of times. It's so vague. How big your hands? What's the size of the drug?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: GURFELD
utterances.sentences: Is it five -- my point is this. It could be 50 times or 500 times a handful of times.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, you got a lot of --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. Just your hand. This is -- a lot of this is what's called that's a new version of virtuous signaling.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's vice signaling. It's the idea of saying like, you know what, I do drugs.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But you vice signaling.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I do. I do. I mean, I've got --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But you think vice signaled.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- I've done every drug but too. And I don't care.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You fake vice signaled.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: In case something happens to you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I -- you're absolutely right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: People don't think it's that abnormal for you to be involved in shenanigans.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: When I get arrested though, everybody will go, that's just Greg.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's just Greg.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, Gutfeld. Wait a second. Did Trump learn this from you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That was great. But let me just say, I think this is politics catching up to the culture.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Because the whole business with like reaper madness, long gone. The whole business even like with stone or people you know hanging out old hippies. Look, you know who you see down at the wellness store? You see a lot of seniors.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: A lot of seniors and people who say I have a medical issue and my doctor prescribes now. And they've got things that you wouldn't believe me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, I've seen you down by the drug store.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I don't think you see me. But you know what?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You see people now with candies, with tincture. I mean, it's unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Tinctures?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, they got all kinds of stuff.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jesse, is it a good way for - it's good way to get people to the polls?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, if Bernie runs this through and they put this on the ballot for initiatives in the swing states. You remember what happened with the gay marriage that brought out a lot of conservatives for Bush. And now if they do this, you know, I don't know if Trump can win if they put marijuana on the ballot nationwide.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, no. Here's what you do. If you're a Republican, you get the Democrats super high. So, they just blow off voting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. You tell them that it's happening November 9th.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That worked with the black folks.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, Jedediah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Always injected.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Always injecting race.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You're about to be a mom.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Have you stopped smoking pot, while you're pregnant.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I have never smoked pot.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Have you stopped beating your husband?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Because drugs make me nervous truly, because I'm a control freak and I don't like to be out of control. So, drugs make me - I do think I've got a contact high once, though, from someone who lived on my floor, who we both know, by the way. We won't mention him, but.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Neal Schultz?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: No. No, actually, comedian, we both know. But yes, I like this topic because I think it forces people to talk about issues of freedom and this started with medical marijuana, which, as you've said, it became such a hot topic when you found out that people who had cancer and people who were living--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But that was a Trojan horse to get it legalized.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And there is other states that have not had the best and they have mixed results.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Yes. But I think--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You get a lot of tax revenue, but you also have a lot of other problem.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: But the idea like all this is a gateway drug. I think it forces people to sort of have this conversation in the modern era with what we know about it now, we know that that's not true. We know a lot of people that smoke, we don't do other drugs. It just forces politicians to kind of be up on what's happening. I just don't like when they say this stuff to try to look cool. That I don't like.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: When Barack Obama in his book said that he did lines of coke.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Do you think he was trying to look cool, Jedediah?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: He might have been.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Or maybe just coming clean in print, so--

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I have to read it. But I think when it's relevant to the discussion and you bring in your own life and a politician does that. I like that. But not when they're trying to look like that cool politician like Kamala Harris does all the time.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Trump is the cleanest one. I don't think he's ever done a drug in his life. PERINO: No, he doesn't.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: He doesn't drink either, right. I don't think he drinks.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: If only.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Are we done? All right. Free speech on campus is under attack. You've heard about this. And now there are new boycott threats and protesters that are shutting down an event featuring, believe it or not, a former ICE director. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Two new examples of liberal campus insanity and the war on free speech, Harvard student run newspapers facing a boycott over running a story about anti-OWS protests. Those students are enraged. The paper dared to seek comment from the agency. And at the University of Pennsylvania, student snowflakes shut down an event featuring a former ICE director, Tom Homan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This First Amendment crackdown on campuses is being exposed in a new documentary from Dennis Prager and Adam Carolla.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You have the right to remain silent. Anything you say will be used against you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You are not listening. I want your job to be taken for me.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: A protest has turned violent at California, Berkeley.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is why we're fighting for the soul of America.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You should be able to share ideas without fear of being fired from your job or shouted down.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You are not to be hurt. This is one of the few things one could say, we have no precedent for in the United States.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Jedediah, when someone's invited to speak on campus, you assume that you want to hear from that speaker. Why don't you think these Far-Left activists want to hear from conservatives? BILA: Because it's threatening. Because it's threatening, because they're so used to living in an academic bubble where everyone agrees and the people who don't agree fall in line or they face punishment. The students get ostracized or the people in administration get ostracized in the faculty rooms. They're so used to everyone caving and they're so worried that the student body might heaven forbid, go to one of these things and just learn something or maybe say, oh, you know what, these people who believe something different than I do. They're not so bad or maybe we've actually thinking for themselves. Heaven forbids. Colleges and universities are turning into the biggest waste of money for parents because you send your kids to school, and this kind of insanity ensues. I mean, can you imagine that there is an anti-ICE protest on a campus and the newspaper just simply covers the event and simply asks for a comment. And now you actually have students protesting. And I want to know how those students got into Harvard or got into a school that supposed to be reputable. If they don't even have the basic knowledge of how basic journalism works. I mean, this is not something that we should even be debating, but it's a sad state of affairs. And I really think parents should look at this and say, do I want to send my kids to an indoctrination camp where they're not going to learn how to think, where their views, if they differ at all from the mainstream, will be completely shot down. I think it's a scary time to be a parent when you look at this stuff and you're sending kids to school?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, if you were invited to speak at a conservative university and the minute you took the mic, all the student started yelling and throwing and just causing chaos and you were unable to speak, how would you feel?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I feel bad. I think that's ridiculous. I mean, I just don't think that's cool. But, you know, I mean, even in this situation, first with the Harvard Crimson, I just think the Crimson did nothing wrong. I mean, I think you should call for comment, right. I think that's what we do. I mean, you want to tell the story in full to the reader. And to say that you're telling in full is to give people the opportunity to speak. Now, I do understand, by the way so what they did doesn't reflect agreement with ICE or disagreement with ICE. It's just journalism. But I do think, I understand the instinct of the people who are protesting. I don't think they're mindless. I don't think that they are venal. I think that they want to call out ICE for breaking up families, for imprisoning children. I think they feel ICE is an abusive place. But here's the thing, even with Tom Homan at the University of Pennsylvania, why wouldn't you want to hear him speak and let people come to their own conclusions about what Tom Homan represents And, you know--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They usually have a Q and A session afterwards.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think it would be very helpful, because I think you could say, you know what, Mr. Homan, I agree, or I disagree. And that's an intellectual exercise.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. This has gotten more prevalent, Dana. PERINO: Well, the best thing that ever happened to any of us is that we were born in America and that people all over the world would love to have- -

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Some of us were, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Were you not born in America?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to say who wasn't.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I can imagine. But it is like really like winning the best lottery in the world because you are born, and you have these freedoms and these values. People are fighting for their lives and in places like Russia, you express yourself, you get thrown in jail. And so, it's all warped. I'm a little disturbed about something. We keep talking about this happening on the campus, but clearly this is something that is being ingrained before they even get to the campus. Isn't that something you automatically suddenly learn when you get to freshman year? It goes earlier and deeper than that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I can't believe Greg said that Tom Homan should have said, all right, you know what, kids, we're just going to put you in cages.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Rest of the lecture.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. I thought that was a little strong. I might get a million points. I'll be fast. Carolla and Prager are middle of the road, guys. He's a comedian. These are normal. They're getting heat for this. And they're basically speaking common sense. But to the question, why won't they let them speak? It's the logical consequences when you personalize politics. If you deem somebody a moral, right, then all their speech is hate speech, then their hate speech becomes a hate crime. Then you could shut out - I don't need to hear them. They were immoral. And then you remove dialog and what's the next step when you remove dialog, violence. The interesting thing about an activist mentality is there's a lot of research or new research that shows, they reject community-based functions, fun things to do with people. Instead, they choose activism because you can exercise power over the people. They're not interested in a back and forth. They're interested in domination. That is why activists like that are always so angry and so friendless. So that's why - that's why there is no back and forth. A, they think you're evil, and B, they don't want to talk to you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But public protest is valuable.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, it is. But this is different. These are--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Except when Republicans do it, then it's a stunt.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Then it's a stunt.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, that wasn't stunt. That wasn't a protest.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Up next, who wants to work just five hours a day. Me. It sounds great, but you may be surprised that you'll have to--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Why increase it.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: The five-hour workday is something most employees can only dream of. But one company is actually trying it out and says workers are just as productive. There are some major catches, including this list of do's and don'ts. Small talk is discouraged. Social media is banned. Phones are kept in backpack. On the plus side, company emails are checked just twice a day and meetings can be no more than 15 minutes. I don't know, Greg, this sounds pretty good to me. What about you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, this is based on an obvious fact that we really don't do eight hours of work. No, we don't. Like an eight-hour day, you do maybe four hours. Everything else is just waiting slowly to die. But if you love your job, if you love your job., this information is meaningless, because if you love your job, you're just thinking about it 24/7. When you're in bed, you can't wait to get to work. You're never off the clock. I mean, there are people at Fox who obviously do not work very hard. Kilmeade comes to mind. This is a guy who like, you know, he gets up so early that - and pretends to go to work. But I see where he is, and nobody is doing. He doesn't work. BILA: Juan, if you take all the distraction away, though, I think it's a good point. How much time do we actually spend looking at Facebook, looking on social media, scrolling through old e-mails? We take all that out, you can be just as productive in less hours, can't you?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, but would you take it out? See, that's the thing.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I mean, I would.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I mean, we're approaching the holiday season. People spend so much time while they're at work shopping online. It's unbelievable to me. But apparently, that's what happens.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's good for the economy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It's good for the economy. All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's part of our job.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I do think there is a lot of distraction and chitchat at work. But on the other hand, for example, in this place, it's important that we have some ability to bounce ideas off each other, to sort of have creative sparks. But I know from people who are writers that there's a general agreement. You can only do about two to three hours of useful work a day after that, you're just sitting around, you're moving stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: After that, it's drinking.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: The only problem I see with this, Jesse is that a boss would be returning to school because you'd have a boss being like, put your phone away, do this. It would turn into an environment where you felt like you weren't being treated as an adult.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, sometimes you work better when you're treated like a child. If you have a boss standing over you and making sure you're working hard, then you're probably going to work a little harder. But when - it's like a substitute.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Come on. It would make you crazy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Or the teachers out of the room like unsupervised study hall. How much work did you get done in unsupervised study hall? But I just want to defend myself for a second, because some of my colleagues have - there is a lot of fake news over here about my workday. If you're waking up and turning on Fox and Friends, you're finding out what's going on in the news.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You turn on Limbaugh at noon from noon to 3, I consider that research.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And then you come in. You prep for this show and then maybe you have Wednesdays with Waters. Maybe you have Hannity. That extends my day all the way into the evening, while you guys are home eating Japanese steak.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You guys or do you want to be more specific?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well no, you're up at five. I'm talking about this cat over here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I also think that well - there is a lot of people who do work from home. I'm not necessarily for it. Some people can be very disciplined. They can work from home. But I do think there is some joy to be had in life of getting to know your coworkers and your friends and--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Be careful.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: In every appropriate way.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I like to get to know you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think it's probably true. Five hours is probably what you do. But I also think that with all the catches and all the - it basically sounds like then you become like a robot.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And I don't like that. BILA: The other thing that this all started with was the four day a week. Everyone saying, oh, well, maybe people could have off on Friday. So, I think they're trying to incentivize workers in this new age where you have a lot of companies where people do--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Robots are getting care.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: It doesn't look 9 to 5. Your robots are not taking over.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Robots are going to say, I'll work 24/7, eight days a week.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You guys go take your time off and then you'll live in the woods - you're eating each other. Jedediah, cannibalism, because we won't have any money.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: You've turned this into a happy place. One More Thing is coming up next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Time for fun, One More Thing. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We just talked about having a five-hour workday. Well, if you're trying to stay out of the rat race, this story is not for you. Dr. Kelly Lambert, Professor of Behavioral Neuroscience and Science in University at Richmond has taught rats how to drive. And the research was done in order to study the brain's ability to change over time and implications, of course, for treating mental health in humans. Well, the rats were raised in a more enriched environment if they were very good at it. They learn how to drive like this in these little vehicles and they were called rat operated vehicles, ROVs. And you know what their little treat were?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Little bits of fruit loops. I mean, what would you do for a fruit loop?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't know. But it sounds like they're hitting the road dent.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I like, but yesterday you did the gourd for the pumpkin. That was good. All right. Halloween is next Thursday. And this is America's top five list of costumes for 2019, according to Google Fright Geist. Number one, it's Pennywise, the Evil Clown from Stephen King's movie IT Chapter 2. Number two, it's old school time. It's a witch broomstick optional. Of course, the adults are going to be Elvira, the mistress of darkness. Number three, it's Spider-Man. Yes. The comic book hero is still very popular. Number four, dinosaurs. Yes. And this year, you can wear an inflatable T-Rex costume inspired by Jurassic Park. Number five, The Descendants. Yes. Villains from the Disney movie. And I want you to get out. Get your fright costume ready and your boo hoo on. All right, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, wait.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. We have a feeding frenzy on a Thursday. Everybody gets excited.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, we are excited. I am excited.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's amazing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Everybody loves cereal. I love cereal. My kids love cereal. Apparently, Greg loves cereal. So, this is what they do at Kellogg's. They put all of their cereals and they mashed them up together in one box. It's called All Together where they have Corn Flakes, Rice Krispies, Frosted Flakes, Fruit Loops, Frosted Mini Weeks and Raisin Bran. And they teamed up with Glad for this idea in order to fight bullying and things like that. It's called All Together. But the best part is they put it in individual boxes in the big box so that you can kind of mix up however you want. You can put Frosted Flakes with the Fruit Loops.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Separate but equal. Yes. That's right. It's Plessy versus Ferguson of cereals.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Is it good?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Delicious.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think this is highly immoral.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That is really good.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's a great idea.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Really good, Kellogg's.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think the environmentalists are going to freak out though.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's indoctrination, I tell you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I love it. Great idea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't need politics in my cereal.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Did your mom ever let you buy the little boxes like this? Like the pack of little boxes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Only on vacation.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what, and the ones left over were like the bran flakes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Brown box. All right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Animals Are Great. Since Jesse is all about tolerance. I've got to be tolerance, too. I'm not a fan of interspecies mingling unless it's platonic. utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's nature. It's the circle of life. They love and then they die. And that is why, Animals Are Great. You don't see that on outnumbered.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: BILA

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: BILA

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Look, I think that it would be I think it'd be a good moment for him. I really do. I think he should do it. It's a great tradition.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Just check that outfit before.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, POLITICAL ANALYST
utterances.utterance: Hello everyone. I'm Juan Williams, along with Jedediah Bila, Jesse Watters, Dana Perino, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City. This is “The Five.” The impeachment battle boiling over on Capitol Hill. Republicans now demanding to know when and who the whistleblower is. And they want that person to testify publicly. It comes as President Trump is praising House Republicans as, quote, "tough and smart" after they stormed the closed-door impeachment hearing. Today, Senator Lindsey Graham introduced a resolution condemning the inquiry. He and other Republicans not happy with how the process is playing out.

utterances.speaker: SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM, R-S.C.
utterances.utterance: I think if we were doing this you'd be beaten by (muted) of us. I think if a Republican were doing to a Democrat what we're doing, you would be all over me.

utterances.speaker: REP. STEVE SCALISE, R-LA
utterances.utterance: Maybe in the Soviet Union this kind of thing is commonplace.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: We've got to stop like thinking that we can use the marquis of Queensberry rules of engagement when we're fighting against the angry pack of rabid hyenas.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Democrats say they will make the impeachment inquiry more transparent with plans for public hearings as soon as mid-November, but they are not backing down. Take a look at Democrats and the media attacking the GOP's tactics.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It looked like a mob scene.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: And they are not flash mobbing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Acted like a mob.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Described the scene like a mob.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Like a mob.

utterances.speaker: MAX BOOT, CNN GLOBAL AFFAIRS ANALYST
utterances.utterance: Lawless mob action.

utterances.speaker: LAURA COATES, CNN LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.utterance: Mob mentality.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: So, what happened yesterday was a high school prank by a bunch of 50-year-old white men.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: You just saw a bunch of white men.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Those are white guys. Those are middle-aged boring nerdy looking white guys.

utterances.speaker: JEFFREY TOOBIN, CNN CHIEF LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.utterance: They looked like just jerks.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Pathetic weenies.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's almost out of the animal house movie.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Just as mad. How do you go home and look at your wives and look at your children?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Well, I think most -- I think --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Just a pathetic, pathetic people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right, Jesse, everybody has got their take on this one way or another. But, I mean, even the Wall Street Journal called that a stunt today. But I would you when you see the Republicans in parts, storming that secure hearing room, aren't they violating House rules? I mean, I think they should be more upset with the founding fathers who wrote the Constitution and said this is the way impeachment is to be conducted rather than just the Democrats.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.utterance: They want to know the truth. They want to know what's going on behind closed doors. Both parties have stunts. The Democrats are the king of stunts. I mean, they ate the fried chicken in the room. They all do sit-ins over guns. The mob action, the Democrats love mob action. That's what they've been doing the less three years. But unfortunately, Juan, this is what happens when you lose elections. The Democrats outvoted the Republicans in the midterms. Pelosi has the gavel. They can do whatever the hell they want. And the Republicans are force to pull the stuff. It's really people who stayed home on election day last time. I mean, if you want to point fingers, they needed more Trump voters and they didn't get them. And now, Trump is getting eaten alive by people on the inside. First it was Comey and McCabe. The transition was a horror show. And then there was all these people working against him, an embassy at the National Security Council and he can't get anything done because every time he tries to do one thing or the other, people cut him down in the dark. And it's really disgraceful. Ukraine is the most corrupt basically, on the entire planet. This place is a mess. We send them billions of dollars. Everyone is getting rich over there, including the Biden family. They colluded with the Democrats last election. It's a Russian speaking country. It's totally a mess. And all the president is trying to do is find out what the hell is going on over there, find out what happened last time, how is everything starting to begin with. He's playing politics. He's trying to fight back. And he's getting killed for it. Now, they are holding secret impeachment hearings. It's disgusting. And all the Republicans want to do is find out what's happening behind closed doors and they can't even share their side of the story, because all the whistleblowers and their lawyers have colluded with Schiff in order to tee this ting up. Now does anyone even care in the administration? They don't even have a team that's fighting this thing. I mean, I've said more things on the show to push back against what's going on than I've seen out of the White House. Where is the Senate? Where is Lindsey Graham? Why isn't he holding hearings? Why isn't he interviewing the people that are testifying behind closed doors? It's time for them to get tougher than they already are. You know, you can say I condemn this. You can send a bunch of guys in to try to find out what's going on, but they need lawyers, they need killers, they need people with experience, parliamentarians who know who to fight this thing. Because right now, it's day after day, week after week, and they are losing the message war.

utterances.speaker: JEDEDIAH BILA, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Tell us how you really feel.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Do you think they need Jesse Watters? I think they need Jesse Watters. Greg, the president though, takes Jesse's position. He says you know what, he encouraged them to pull that stunt. In fact, he says now that Republicans who oppose him are, here I'm quoting, "human scum."

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Worse than the most dangerous Democrats. How do you react to that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. He called them human scum. It could have been worse; he could have called them Democrats. Joke. I love the Dems. By the way, I feel bad for the Democrats and the media. They were preferring a Mitt Romney who got Candy Crowley. You don't have it in the White House now. This guy likes to punch back and he's going to do it. Donny Deutsch calling someone a weenie. This guy is an eight-pack of ball park franks. I mean, he still wears Speedo's under his suit. OK. That's what a weenie is. But here's the deal. Calling those Republicans out as a bunch of white guys, what you're doing is you are injecting color into something where it has no relevance. So, what's that -- what's that called when you inject race into something where there is no racist variable? It's called race- baiting. So, CNN and MSNBC are engaging in something incredibly pretty dangerous. They always have it. It's getting pretty bad. They are seeking to divide a country based on pigment. That's what they are doing. And when I see that, it makes me realize how awful the media is. And if you subtracted the media from the story, we probably get closer to the truth. And to be honest, the truth is the media and the Democrats would prefer only one kind of resistance, their own. Which is why they are calling these guys a mob. That's why they create hate hoaxes. They demean supporters. They fabricate racial animus. They do that because they're trying to scare the way they scare like anybody who believes their pack, whether it's Candace Owens or Peter Thiel. If they're not, you know, if you are black and you are not a liberal, if you are a gay and not a conservative, you're dead. So, I just think, I think it's good to fight back. I don't think it was a mob. They are doing the job that the journalist -- like journalists prefer to get it spoon-fed to them from Adam Schiff.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The Republicans are actually doing what journalists are doing. They are knocking on the door and saying, give us the facts.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, in fact though, here we have a situation, Dana, where it looks like they're complaining about process. Complaining about the whistleblower. Always the whistleblower someone with some political affiliation opposed to the president. They are complaining about things because the facts as we understand them from these hearings, are really hurting the president.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: What they are saying is that they don't -- you don't have enough transparency to be able to make that determination. That's what the Republicans are saying. And we know the saying if you, if the facts are on your side, pound the facts.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And if not, pound the table.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And so, this is called a stunt by the media and it was a stunt. But remember when AOC first got to Congress and when the first act that she did was go and sit-in on Nancy Pelosi's office to protest climate change. That was a protest and that was considered something like that was you're exercising your right. And it was bringing good attention to something. But when Republicans do it, then it's called a stunt. Either way, it works in order to get yourself in the media. And basically, the Republicans were able to win a news cycle yesterday. They hadn't been able to do it, to Jesse's point up unto now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, do you think though, Jedediah, that when we talked about the whistleblower, is there, from the Republican perspective, a fundamental misunderstanding of the law? Because the reason there is a whistleblower law is to protect the whistleblower against intimidation or pressure coming from powerful people like the most powerful man in the country, Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I think that's typically true. The problem with the whistleblower is that there have been so many inconsistencies in terms of what that person has said. There are these allegations now of serious political bias, of not only being a registered Democrat but having worked with high-profile Democrats in the past. There is this concept of the secondhand information, where did this whistleblower get that information? How credible are those sources? And then also just the fact that the whistleblower didn't check that box that said yes in fact he had spoken to the likes of Adam Schiff ahead of time. So, I think all of the questions around the whistleblower are the problem. So, Republicans, I'm not a big fan of them storming a hearing. That's all nonsense. But I do think that they are concerned about Adam Schiff as being an honest person is real. I mean, he has lied repeatedly several times throughout this. And also, just concerns about the whistleblower. In this particular case, seem -- seems to be more concern. I would be looking at this and saying, we need to hear from where this information came from.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: From the whistleblower.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Well, yes, because there's too many red flags. It's uncomfortable.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I'm thinking a whistleblower's account-

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: But I understand what you're saying about the law.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right, the law is obvious.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I'm saying that his account also then has been confirmed on so many levels by what we've learned. But --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: But it also has a ton of holes in it is the problem.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This whistleblower is what's important than the actual transcript of the phone call.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Which we already heard.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And it was perfect.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is all a circus.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It was a perfect --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: it was perfect.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you believe that.

utterances.utterance: Like my jacket.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.utterance: He destroyed the lives, that's what she says.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well here's what I think, Greg. I find this very curious that conservatives for most of Facebook's like have said, you guys are biased against conservative content. utterances.utterance: He said he would.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
