utterances.utterance: -- he thinks is unconstitutional.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. He's doing that to stir up his base with lies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan, that's not a lie. It's an opinion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There it is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: My point is --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Greg said to me, who cares if he lies?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly. It's an opinion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And it's not my problem.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And when AQOC puts out an ad that says the earth is going to die in 12 years --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is that --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, that's election -- if she can't substantiate it, get it out. But I don't know that she can substantiate.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, it's more of a lie to say we're going to die in 12 years.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I see. You guys are jumping now because you know what, that's a losing --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Remember this?

utterances.speaker: BILL CLINTON, FORMER PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: I experimented with marijuana a time or two and I didn't like it. And didn't inhale --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Smoking marijuana used to be a taboo subject for candidates running president. You might remember when Bill Clinton shocked the nation by admitting this.

utterances.speaker: CLINTON
utterances.utterance: I experimented with marijuana a time or two and I didn't like it. And didn't inhale, and never tried it again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, times are changing and our country has since evolved. Many 2020 candidates are now admitting to smoking pot as they call as they call for a nationwide decriminalization. Mayor Pete Buttigieg is just the latest example.

utterances.speaker: MAYOR PETE BUTTIGIEG, D-IND., PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: I had a handful of times a long time ago. And I've also encountered a lot of people whose lives have really been shaken by the old war on drugs approach.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And Mayor Pete is not alone.

utterances.speaker: CHARLAMAGNE THA GOD, CO-HOST, THE BREAKFAST CLUB
utterances.utterance: Have you ever smoked?

utterances.speaker: SEN. KAMALA HARRIS, D-CALIF., PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: I have.

utterances.speaker: GOD
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.utterance: And I -- and I did inhale.

utterances.speaker: GOD
utterances.utterance: You did inhale.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.utterance: It was a long time ago. But yes.

utterances.speaker: GOD
utterances.utterance: Have you ever smoked?

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS, I-VT, D-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: A few times.

utterances.speaker: GOD
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: I didn't do a whole lot for me. My recollection is I nearly call for my brains out, so it's not my -- my cup of tea.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, Bernie might have been the most honest one. Bernie Sanders also releasing a new marijuana plan. He wants to have a legalization of marijuana for in the first 100 days of his presidency if he's elected. And he says he will do for this executive action and create a White House clemency in board that would help all those people that have low level of marijuana offenses. So, I'm not a big expert in this field. I'm glad I'm leaving this so I could just ask you. What do you think, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, you left out two other candidates. Joe Biden admitted to mainlining (Inaudible). And Liz Warren also says she smokes a peace pipe regularly. Anyway, I love how -- finally politicians have moved away from saying I experimented with drugs, as if you were like an Isaac Newton in your dorm room, with that cradling a bang for four years. yes, I experimented. Or it's like, or like I think I'm pretty sure he said I tried it a handful of times. Nobody tries drugs. You do drugs, OK? You can try mountain climbing or you can try -- but when you're doing the drugs, it goes inside your body. You are no longer trying them. They are inside you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I experimented with mountain climbing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I experimented. It drives me crazy. And also, the handful of times. It's so vague. How big your hands? What's the size of the drug?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: GURFELD
utterances.utterance: Is it five -- my point is this. It could be 50 times or 500 times a handful of times.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you got a lot of --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Just your hand. This is -- a lot of this is what's called that's a new version of virtuous signaling.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's vice signaling. It's the idea of saying like, you know what, I do drugs.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But you vice signaling.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I do. I do. I mean, I've got --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But you think vice signaled.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- I've done every drug but too. And I don't care.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You fake vice signaled.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: In case something happens to you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I -- you're absolutely right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: People don't think it's that abnormal for you to be involved in shenanigans.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: When I get arrested though, everybody will go, that's just Greg.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's just Greg.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, Gutfeld. Wait a second. Did Trump learn this from you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That was great. But let me just say, I think this is politics catching up to the culture.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because the whole business with like reaper madness, long gone. The whole business even like with stone or people you know hanging out old hippies. Look, you know who you see down at the wellness store? You see a lot of seniors.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A lot of seniors and people who say I have a medical issue and my doctor prescribes now. And they've got things that you wouldn't believe me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, I've seen you down by the drug store.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I don't think you see me. But you know what?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You see people now with candies, with tincture. I mean, it's unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Tinctures?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, they got all kinds of stuff.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, is it a good way for - it's good way to get people to the polls?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I mean, if Bernie runs this through and they put this on the ballot for initiatives in the swing states. You remember what happened with the gay marriage that brought out a lot of conservatives for Bush. And now if they do this, you know, I don't know if Trump can win if they put marijuana on the ballot nationwide.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no. Here's what you do. If you're a Republican, you get the Democrats super high. So, they just blow off voting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. You tell them that it's happening November 9th.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That worked with the black folks.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, Jedediah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Always injected.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Always injecting race.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You're about to be a mom.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Have you stopped smoking pot, while you're pregnant.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I have never smoked pot.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Have you stopped beating your husband?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Because drugs make me nervous truly, because I'm a control freak and I don't like to be out of control. So, drugs make me - I do think I've got a contact high once, though, from someone who lived on my floor, who we both know, by the way. We won't mention him, but.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Neal Schultz?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: No. No, actually, comedian, we both know. But yes, I like this topic because I think it forces people to talk about issues of freedom and this started with medical marijuana, which, as you've said, it became such a hot topic when you found out that people who had cancer and people who were living--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But that was a Trojan horse to get it legalized.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And there is other states that have not had the best and they have mixed results.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yes. But I think--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You get a lot of tax revenue, but you also have a lot of other problem.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: But the idea like all this is a gateway drug. I think it forces people to sort of have this conversation in the modern era with what we know about it now, we know that that's not true. We know a lot of people that smoke, we don't do other drugs. It just forces politicians to kind of be up on what's happening. I just don't like when they say this stuff to try to look cool. That I don't like.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When Barack Obama in his book said that he did lines of coke.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you think he was trying to look cool, Jedediah?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: He might have been.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Or maybe just coming clean in print, so--

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I have to read it. But I think when it's relevant to the discussion and you bring in your own life and a politician does that. I like that. But not when they're trying to look like that cool politician like Kamala Harris does all the time.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Trump is the cleanest one. I don't think he's ever done a drug in his life. PERINO: No, he doesn't.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: He doesn't drink either, right. I don't think he drinks.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: If only.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Are we done? All right. Free speech on campus is under attack. You've heard about this. And now there are new boycott threats and protesters that are shutting down an event featuring, believe it or not, a former ICE director. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Two new examples of liberal campus insanity and the war on free speech, Harvard student run newspapers facing a boycott over running a story about anti-OWS protests. Those students are enraged. The paper dared to seek comment from the agency. And at the University of Pennsylvania, student snowflakes shut down an event featuring a former ICE director, Tom Homan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This First Amendment crackdown on campuses is being exposed in a new documentary from Dennis Prager and Adam Carolla.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You have the right to remain silent. Anything you say will be used against you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: You are not listening. I want your job to be taken for me.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: A protest has turned violent at California, Berkeley.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: This is why we're fighting for the soul of America.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You should be able to share ideas without fear of being fired from your job or shouted down.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You are not to be hurt. This is one of the few things one could say, we have no precedent for in the United States.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Jedediah, when someone's invited to speak on campus, you assume that you want to hear from that speaker. Why don't you think these Far-Left activists want to hear from conservatives? BILA: Because it's threatening. Because it's threatening, because they're so used to living in an academic bubble where everyone agrees and the people who don't agree fall in line or they face punishment. The students get ostracized or the people in administration get ostracized in the faculty rooms. They're so used to everyone caving and they're so worried that the student body might heaven forbid, go to one of these things and just learn something or maybe say, oh, you know what, these people who believe something different than I do. They're not so bad or maybe we've actually thinking for themselves. Heaven forbids. Colleges and universities are turning into the biggest waste of money for parents because you send your kids to school, and this kind of insanity ensues. I mean, can you imagine that there is an anti-ICE protest on a campus and the newspaper just simply covers the event and simply asks for a comment. And now you actually have students protesting. And I want to know how those students got into Harvard or got into a school that supposed to be reputable. If they don't even have the basic knowledge of how basic journalism works. I mean, this is not something that we should even be debating, but it's a sad state of affairs. And I really think parents should look at this and say, do I want to send my kids to an indoctrination camp where they're not going to learn how to think, where their views, if they differ at all from the mainstream, will be completely shot down. I think it's a scary time to be a parent when you look at this stuff and you're sending kids to school?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, if you were invited to speak at a conservative university and the minute you took the mic, all the student started yelling and throwing and just causing chaos and you were unable to speak, how would you feel?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I feel bad. I think that's ridiculous. I mean, I just don't think that's cool. But, you know, I mean, even in this situation, first with the Harvard Crimson, I just think the Crimson did nothing wrong. I mean, I think you should call for comment, right. I think that's what we do. I mean, you want to tell the story in full to the reader. And to say that you're telling in full is to give people the opportunity to speak. Now, I do understand, by the way so what they did doesn't reflect agreement with ICE or disagreement with ICE. It's just journalism. But I do think, I understand the instinct of the people who are protesting. I don't think they're mindless. I don't think that they are venal. I think that they want to call out ICE for breaking up families, for imprisoning children. I think they feel ICE is an abusive place. But here's the thing, even with Tom Homan at the University of Pennsylvania, why wouldn't you want to hear him speak and let people come to their own conclusions about what Tom Homan represents And, you know--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They usually have a Q and A session afterwards.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think it would be very helpful, because I think you could say, you know what, Mr. Homan, I agree, or I disagree. And that's an intellectual exercise.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. This has gotten more prevalent, Dana. PERINO: Well, the best thing that ever happened to any of us is that we were born in America and that people all over the world would love to have- -

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Some of us were, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Were you not born in America?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to say who wasn't.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I can imagine. But it is like really like winning the best lottery in the world because you are born, and you have these freedoms and these values. People are fighting for their lives and in places like Russia, you express yourself, you get thrown in jail. And so, it's all warped. I'm a little disturbed about something. We keep talking about this happening on the campus, but clearly this is something that is being ingrained before they even get to the campus. Isn't that something you automatically suddenly learn when you get to freshman year? It goes earlier and deeper than that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I can't believe Greg said that Tom Homan should have said, all right, you know what, kids, we're just going to put you in cages.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Rest of the lecture.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I thought that was a little strong. I might get a million points. I'll be fast. Carolla and Prager are middle of the road, guys. He's a comedian. These are normal. They're getting heat for this. And they're basically speaking common sense. But to the question, why won't they let them speak? It's the logical consequences when you personalize politics. If you deem somebody a moral, right, then all their speech is hate speech, then their hate speech becomes a hate crime. Then you could shut out - I don't need to hear them. They were immoral. And then you remove dialog and what's the next step when you remove dialog, violence. The interesting thing about an activist mentality is there's a lot of research or new research that shows, they reject community-based functions, fun things to do with people. Instead, they choose activism because you can exercise power over the people. They're not interested in a back and forth. They're interested in domination. That is why activists like that are always so angry and so friendless. So that's why - that's why there is no back and forth. A, they think you're evil, and B, they don't want to talk to you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But public protest is valuable.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, it is. But this is different. These are--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Except when Republicans do it, then it's a stunt.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Then it's a stunt.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, that wasn't stunt. That wasn't a protest.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Up next, who wants to work just five hours a day. Me. It sounds great, but you may be surprised that you'll have to--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why increase it.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: The five-hour workday is something most employees can only dream of. But one company is actually trying it out and says workers are just as productive. There are some major catches, including this list of do's and don'ts. Small talk is discouraged. Social media is banned. Phones are kept in backpack. On the plus side, company emails are checked just twice a day and meetings can be no more than 15 minutes. I don't know, Greg, this sounds pretty good to me. What about you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, this is based on an obvious fact that we really don't do eight hours of work. No, we don't. Like an eight-hour day, you do maybe four hours. Everything else is just waiting slowly to die. But if you love your job, if you love your job., this information is meaningless, because if you love your job, you're just thinking about it 24/7. When you're in bed, you can't wait to get to work. You're never off the clock. I mean, there are people at Fox who obviously do not work very hard. Kilmeade comes to mind. This is a guy who like, you know, he gets up so early that - and pretends to go to work. But I see where he is, and nobody is doing. He doesn't work. BILA: Juan, if you take all the distraction away, though, I think it's a good point. How much time do we actually spend looking at Facebook, looking on social media, scrolling through old e-mails? We take all that out, you can be just as productive in less hours, can't you?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, but would you take it out? See, that's the thing.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I mean, I would.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I mean, we're approaching the holiday season. People spend so much time while they're at work shopping online. It's unbelievable to me. But apparently, that's what happens.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's good for the economy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's good for the economy. All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's part of our job.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I do think there is a lot of distraction and chitchat at work. But on the other hand, for example, in this place, it's important that we have some ability to bounce ideas off each other, to sort of have creative sparks. But I know from people who are writers that there's a general agreement. You can only do about two to three hours of useful work a day after that, you're just sitting around, you're moving stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: After that, it's drinking.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: The only problem I see with this, Jesse is that a boss would be returning to school because you'd have a boss being like, put your phone away, do this. It would turn into an environment where you felt like you weren't being treated as an adult.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, sometimes you work better when you're treated like a child. If you have a boss standing over you and making sure you're working hard, then you're probably going to work a little harder. But when - it's like a substitute.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Come on. It would make you crazy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Or the teachers out of the room like unsupervised study hall. How much work did you get done in unsupervised study hall? But I just want to defend myself for a second, because some of my colleagues have - there is a lot of fake news over here about my workday. If you're waking up and turning on Fox and Friends, you're finding out what's going on in the news.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You turn on Limbaugh at noon from noon to 3, I consider that research.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And then you come in. You prep for this show and then maybe you have Wednesdays with Waters. Maybe you have Hannity. That extends my day all the way into the evening, while you guys are home eating Japanese steak.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You guys or do you want to be more specific?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well no, you're up at five. I'm talking about this cat over here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I also think that well - there is a lot of people who do work from home. I'm not necessarily for it. Some people can be very disciplined. They can work from home. But I do think there is some joy to be had in life of getting to know your coworkers and your friends and--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Be careful.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In every appropriate way.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I like to get to know you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think it's probably true. Five hours is probably what you do. But I also think that with all the catches and all the - it basically sounds like then you become like a robot.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I don't like that. BILA: The other thing that this all started with was the four day a week. Everyone saying, oh, well, maybe people could have off on Friday. So, I think they're trying to incentivize workers in this new age where you have a lot of companies where people do--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Robots are getting care.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: It doesn't look 9 to 5. Your robots are not taking over.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Robots are going to say, I'll work 24/7, eight days a week.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You guys go take your time off and then you'll live in the woods - you're eating each other. Jedediah, cannibalism, because we won't have any money.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You've turned this into a happy place. One More Thing is coming up next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Time for fun, One More Thing. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We just talked about having a five-hour workday. Well, if you're trying to stay out of the rat race, this story is not for you. Dr. Kelly Lambert, Professor of Behavioral Neuroscience and Science in University at Richmond has taught rats how to drive. And the research was done in order to study the brain's ability to change over time and implications, of course, for treating mental health in humans. Well, the rats were raised in a more enriched environment if they were very good at it. They learn how to drive like this in these little vehicles and they were called rat operated vehicles, ROVs. And you know what their little treat were?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Little bits of fruit loops. I mean, what would you do for a fruit loop?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. But it sounds like they're hitting the road dent.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I like, but yesterday you did the gourd for the pumpkin. That was good. All right. Halloween is next Thursday. And this is America's top five list of costumes for 2019, according to Google Fright Geist. Number one, it's Pennywise, the Evil Clown from Stephen King's movie IT Chapter 2. Number two, it's old school time. It's a witch broomstick optional. Of course, the adults are going to be Elvira, the mistress of darkness. Number three, it's Spider-Man. Yes. The comic book hero is still very popular. Number four, dinosaurs. Yes. And this year, you can wear an inflatable T-Rex costume inspired by Jurassic Park. Number five, The Descendants. Yes. Villains from the Disney movie. And I want you to get out. Get your fright costume ready and your boo hoo on. All right, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, wait.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry, Jesse.
